Patch Set 21:

(2 comments)
Also missing documentation in Redfish.md
Documented common error.  you're recreating functions that already exists in sensor.hpp.  please look at how the existing sensor things determine this, and make yours similar.

> you're recreating functions that already exists in sensor.hpp.

Sorry, I am not following. could you please explain more?

Hi, rule 12 
https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/master/COMMON_ERRORS.md#12-imprecise-matching

Use sdbusplus::message::object_path instead

It's not just rule 12 here.  The core issue here is that we have code that does this lookup performantly, using the existing associations, and correctly to dbus interfaces that was ignored and rewritten from scratch.  If new code is truly required (which I'm not convinced it is) that's fine, but it needs to be doing essentially the same operation.
Acknowledged
nit, handle, not handler
Done
Old style of logging, see https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/51587/23/http/http_client.hpp
Ack
Common error.  Non trivial lambda
Done
This should only be looking under the appropriate type in the object path.

> This should only be looking under the appropriate type in the object path.

you mean: /xyz/openbmc_project/sensors/fan_tach & /xyz/openbmc_project/sensors/temperature & /xyz/openbmc_project/sensors/fan_pwm ？
Yes, defined in https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/blob/master/yaml/xyz/openbmc_project/Sensor/Value.interface.yaml#L13
Acknowledged
Can you call out the associations you are using to make this work?
Acknowledged
Please go through and unresolve comments that you've only ACKed

I've looked through the ACKed comments. I believe between earlier changes and the most recent patch set they have all been addressed.

I've edited the commit message to document the associations used to obtain the sensor data.
In the future, please leave un-resolved threads open.  It helps maintainers track what's been fixed, versus what the author has agreed to but might not have fixed yet.

Why do you need the ret? 
Do just: 
"return true;"
Removed this function.
Can you "return false" ?
Removed this function.
non trivial lambda.
Acknowledged

I see nothing in this patchset that's creating this as an array or calling emplace_back/push_back, which makes me believe that this test result is from another system, and not a result of this patchset.  Is it possible that this patchset wasn't actually tested?

NO, we tested it and Validator passed.

https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/65286/7/redfish-core/lib/thermal_metrics.hpp#34
This is an array, but the writing method is different. I have updated it in the new patch as per your comment.

The afterGetTemperatureValue() function calls emplace_back to add each entry to the TemperatureReadingsCelsius array.
Additionally getTemperatureReadingsCelsius() now creates the empty TemperatureReadingsCelsius array.

I've tested with hardware simulator for Rainier hardware.

The Redfish validator does not validate the DataSourceUri. This was reported and I've updated the issue to indicate ThermalMetrics path has similar issue.
https://github.com/DMTF/Redfish-Service-Validator/issues/598

I've manually checked the DataSourceUri being produced.
I'm still not sure how we can create an array without calling push_back, but this patchset has changed that this commit is probably invalid now.
just wrap your json in triple backticks.  No need to add line breaks in a json statement.
Done

This is an array of objects.  You need to call out the properties you've implemented

TemperatureReadingCelcius/Reading

etc.
Done
You call this tempArray, but it isn't an array?  Maybe you meant tempObject?  I would expect this to be an array.
Acknowledged
Please don't resolve comments that aren't done.  Go through and reopen the ones that aren't complete.
Done
Isn't this incorrect.  Sensor Ids include the name and type.  Did this link work in your testing?

Please answer my question.  Did you test that the links your code produced were correct?

You're quoting a DTMF example (which is not the specification) that was not taken on an openbmc system.  "SysBrdTemp" in the example is a uri segment that the server has control over, and on openbmc, doesn't match the example you've given.

I would expect that your tests would fail, which is why I'm asking if they were run recently.  If they're not failing, then I'm misunderstanding something.

> Please answer my question.  Did you test that the links your code produced were correct?

Yes, validator passed, and ran for a while on fp5280g3 and rainier.

> Did you test that the links your code produced were correct?

I didn't ask if the validator passed.  I asked if you tested the links.  The validator doesn't test DataSourceUri links.
I've changed the way DataSourceUri is being built for these entries. I have confirmed the corrected link matches the full sensor and can be retrieved using curl.
Done

"This property shall contain the name of the device associated with this sensor."

This doesn't look correct to that description, as you're putting in the sensor odata.id, not the device name.  Please remove.
Acknowledged
not resolved.
Removed `DeviceName` on patch-9.
Changed DataSourceUri to be built using redfish::sensor_utils::getSensorId().
Done

Lots of this method looks incorrect.  Can we just use the same method that we use in sensors.hpp?

sensors::handleSensorGet

That seems like a good idea to share code to avoid problems like the above.

> Lots of this method looks incorrect.

Could you please point out what exactly is incorrect?

> sensors::handleSensorGet

I checked this method, but I do not know how to implement `DeviceName` and `Reading`. I do not think we can use this method instead.

> > Lots of this method looks incorrect.
> 

Compare your code to handleSensorGet, and you will see some very obvious differences in how the properties are generated.

> 
> > sensors::handleSensorGet
> 
> I checked this method, but I do not know how to implement `DeviceName` and `Reading`. I do not think we can use this method instead.

handleSensorGet doesn't currently implement DeviceName, so I'm not sure why that relates.  I would assume that DeviceName would need to be implemented in handleSensorGet, FIRST, before we could use it in ThermalSubsystem.

How to implement `TemperatureReadingsCelsius` in `handleSensorGet` method?

Yes, they do have similarities, but the properties they expose are completely different. Why use this method instead?

If there is a problem with the current logic, please point it out. At least for now, handleSensorGet is not a universal method.

> How to implement `TemperatureReadingsCelsius` in `handleSensorGet` method?

Add a method call arg called excerpt, that here is true, and in the other code is false.  Then, within that code, branch where appropriate such that the "excerpt" of the sensor is produced.

> 
> Yes, they do have similarities, but the properties they expose are completely different. Why use this method instead?

They're based on the same schema.  What do you mean the properties they produce are completely different?

> 
> If there is a problem with the current logic, please point it out. At least for now, handleSensorGet is not a universal method.

I'm avoiding pointing out the logic errors, because it will miss the fact that we've completely rewritten something that produces the same schema.  if we agree that we should write completely new code for this, at that point in time I will start pointing out the issues in this patchset, but given that it will likely all be condensed into sensor.hpp and associated sensor utils, that seems like a waste of effort.

I've modified this to use a common function. I didn't use the handleSensorGet() function as the common function since it expects to put the response directly into the asyncResp. Since here we need to build an array I have different wrappers.

The objectPropertiesToJson() function where the properties for the sensor are filled in is common for the handleSensorGet() path and this path as well. It understands if a chassisSubNode is an excerpt and limits what properties are built for the excerpts.

Right now mostly this is just skipping things, but I'm expecting when other sensor excerpts are implemented that some of the other properties may be added for excerpts as well. I'm expecting the combination of the chassisSubNode and the sensorType will be used to determine which properties are included for a particular call to build a sensor Json representation.

> I've modified this to use a common function. I didn't use the handleSensorGet() function as the common function since it expects to put the response directly into the asyncResp. Since here we need to build an array I have different wrappers.

We can modify handleSensorGet to do whatever we need it to.  What I don't want is the same keys declared in two places, and I want to make it obvious when changes are made to sensor, that the excerpt version is corrected as well.

> 
> The objectPropertiesToJson() function where the properties for the sensor are filled in is common for the handleSensorGet() path and this path as well. It understands if a chassisSubNode is an excerpt and limits what properties are built for the excerpts.
> 
> Right now mostly this is just skipping things, but I'm expecting when other sensor excerpts are implemented that some of the other properties may be added for excerpts as well. I'm expecting the combination of the chassisSubNode and the sensorType will be used to determine which properties are included for a particular call to build a sensor Json representation.
Looks like you did this in the way i'd expect, so we should be good.
depth 1.
Done
Do you mean to use the 3 single quotation marks instead of double quotation marks?   (\`\`\`)
I think both double quotes and single quotes are OK. Is there any explicit provision that we must use single quotes?
I meant - did you try to use triple backticks (\`\`\`), rather than triple quotes?
Done
nit, just declare as nlohmann::json::object_t

I've changed how the properties are being gathered. It is now using a common function which expects a nlohmann::json type. So I'm leaving the declaration the same since changing it to an object requires casting to send to the common function. I feel that is less clear.
Agreed.  Arguably we should've used object_t in the Response class.

Most of the other places, use `subtree' here.
Isn't it better to use it as common?
```
const dbus::utility::MapperGetSubTreeResponse& subtree
```

I will update all comments after this patch is merged:
https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/+/69008
Done
Wouldn't this be better with `BMCWEB_LOG_ERROR`?
Done

there's nothing checking that the other end of this is a sensor.  In this case, maybe we don't need to?  I'm not sure on that one, but given that's a problem on a bunch of the other patches, it's worth discussing.

I'm not sure either whether the check is necessary. I added a check just in case. On a mismatch the object will be skipped for adding to the TemperatureReadingsCelsius array but not treated as an error.
Done
Please answer in your commit message why this is useful, as opposed to just using SensorCollection.
Added information on why use of ThermalMetrics is useful.
Done
Do we need any new unit tests here?
FYI. I'm going to start working on addressing the code review comments of this commit.
This is looking much closer.  Thank you for continuing to push on it.
Done

I'm hesitant to add additional checking for the ChassisSubNode::thermalNode and ChassisSubNode::powerNode types. Those are deprecated and not used for our hardware so I have trouble regression testing changes there.

As this was originally coded the following branch could be taken even if (ChassisSubNode == powerNode). (I.e. The chassisSubNode here was only ever checked for ChassisSubNode::sensorsNode. All other branches were determined by the sensorType instead.)

I'll try to restructure without changing the existing checks to avoid regressing the deprecated paths.

I don't think isExcerptNode helps with complexity here given how simple it is, and how we're already doing compares here..  I keep having to refer to it to figure out which branches get hit;  Especially here, where we do isExcerptNode, then immediately check chassisSubNode != ChassisSubNode::thermalMetricsNode, which seems like it's the same compare just done twice?  I'm not positive on that, but I suspect just inlining that helper would make this more clear.

Yes I see how this code structure is not clear.

I was trying to code this to make it easier in the future if a sensor excerpt later included some of these properties from a sensor. I wanted any of the excerpts to take the same path as the ChassisSubNode::sensorsNode and then do additional checking to control which properties were actually included.

For ThermalMetrics, TemperatureReadingsCelsius the only property being retrieved for the excerpt is the "Reading" value. Most of this function is not needed for this sensor excerpt. (The schema defines other properties which we are not including. Additionally some of the other sensor excerpts define multiple properties.)

I will restructure this to try to make it clearer for what is being done today. If other properties are included for sensor excerpts in the future it can be addressed at that point how best to add them clearly.
are we certain that Excerpt properties don't contain a type?

From my understanding of the schemas involved the excerpt properties don't contain a type:

- The @odata.type is a defined and required property of ThermalMetrics (https://redfish.dmtf.org/schemas/v1/ThermalMetrics.v1_0_1.json). That is being set in existing function doThermalMetrics().

- The SensorArrayExcerpt properties don't include @odata.type in the schema (http://redfish.dmtf.org/schemas/v1/Sensor.v1_9_0.json#/definitions/SensorArrayExcerpt).

- One of the mockups which has ThermalMetrics also only show the @odata.type as a property of ThermalMetrics but not the excerpts. (https://redfish.dmtf.org/redfish/mockups/v1/1448  Follow links to -> https://redfish.dmtf.org/redfish/mockups/v1/1448#Chassis--1U--ThermalSubsystem--ThermalMetrics)

The mockup moved but that is what it shows (no type)
https://redfish.dmtf.org/redfish/mockups/v1/1518
I've restructured for clarity. I've moved the check for excerpts to the equivalent location for each of these if/else blocks.
Done

Reading is marked
<Annotation Term="Redfish.Excerpt"/>

In the spec.  That means it's required to be included in excerpt mode, right?
nvm, i got this mixed up with the fan reading patch.

if I'm reading this logic right, this seems like a very complex way of just creating an else branch that does nothing?

I suspect just adding the (sensorType != "power" && !excerpt).


I still think excerpt as a bool would make more sense, even if it's not passed in as an arg.

This is one of the places I was coding for the future.

The fan_tach SpeedRPM property is set in here and would also be part of a fan excerpt. (Ignoring the percentage problems for the moment.)

So I thought for the future it would make sense for the excerpts to take this same branch and then within this branch adjust which properties are being included.

I'm restructuring based on what is needed today and will leave the handling of future excerpts for when those commits are coded.

I've added a local bool variable isExcerpt() that is determined from the chassisSubNode. I'd like to keep the isExcerptNode() utility function as it can be unit tested and there should be other excerpt subnode types added in the future.
Why does this need to be an argument at this point?  It's only ever ThermalSubsystem

I was setting this up for more sensor excerpts coming in future commits.

I thought it would be easiest to go ahead and set this function up to be generic so it could handle other ChassisSubNode excerpt types as well. (E.g. EnvironmentMetrics)

Okay with that approach, or would you rather I remove the parameter now and add it when I work on those other commits?
Acknowledged
I'm not following why this code needs to exist?  We're just verifying that the patch functions work by computing things twice?

For the sensor excerpt paths we have the D-Bus path not the Redfish sensor URI path to the sensor.

The Redfish schemas for the sensor excerpts define the "DataSourceUri" to the Redfish URI for the sensor used to obtain the properties being excerpted.

The objectPropertiesToJson() function expects sensorType and sensorName rather than the D-Bus path.

So I decided it would be cleanest to add a wrapper for the sensor excerpts. The goal is to have a common place to set the "DataSourceUri" consistently for the excerpts. I also decided to call objectPropertiesToJson() here since it already had to determine the sensorName and sensorType in order to set the "DataSourceUri".

I'll add a bit more to the comments for the function to help clarify.

> For the sensor excerpt paths we have the D-Bus path not the Redfish sensor URI path to the sensor.
> 
> The Redfish schemas for the sensor excerpts define the "DataSourceUri" to the Redfish URI for the sensor used to obtain the properties being excerpted.
> 
> The objectPropertiesToJson() function expects sensorType and sensorName rather than the D-Bus path.


dbus path is /xyz/openbmc_project/sensors/<sensortype>/<sensorname>

redfish path is
/redfish/v1/Chassis/chassis/Sensors/<sensortype>_<sensorname>

One is trivially convertible to the other.

> 
> So I decided it would be cleanest to add a wrapper for the sensor excerpts. The goal is to have a common place to set the "DataSourceUri" consistently for the excerpts. I also decided to call objectPropertiesToJson() here since it already had to determine the sensorName and sensorType in order to set the "DataSourceUri".
> 
> I'll add a bit more to the comments for the function to help clarify.

sensorTypeExpected is the part I don't understand.

I added the sensorTypeExpected check to try to address the review comment: https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/65286/comment/94939e43_9b46a632/

The current caller is only expecting to see temperature sensors in the array it builds. It does have the sensorType in the D-Bus object path it is processing. But I thought it might be common for these sensor excerpts to only get data for sensors of an expected type. So I thought it would be useful to package that into this wrapper function.

Right, the problem is that if you're getting for a single sensor type, that's trivial to do in your mapper call before starting, like you do on line 109.

I'm not that worried about it.
pass callbacks by std::move and && please
Done
The general rule is that callbacks should always be called.  If there was a processing error, return the error.  That allows callbacks to handle errors generically.
That makes a lot of sense. I've corrected this to follow this rule.
Done
same here.

I've changed it although to get it to compile and clang-tidy to not complain I had to get rid of the std::bind_front() here and replace it with a lambda.

clang-tidy complained about the const and std::move() so I removed the const qualifier for the callback as well.
rightfully so.

We're initting this and count a little early here;  We should only init after we know the mapper hasn't errored, otherwise we'll return an empty array when really we should've returned an error only (no empty array).
Good point, I've moved this into handleTemperatureReadingsCelsius()
Done
Is this inside L403 `if (!isExcerpt){}` block or outside?

It is inside L403 if block. That check goes from L403 - L443.

(I turn on the "All" setting for "Ignore Whitespace" in gerrit for looking at the diffs for this commit. It makes it easier to see where the added if blocks start and end.)
Acknowledged

This is already inside `L547: if(!isExcerpt)`.
So, this can be
```
        else if (sensorType != "power")
```
Good catch, that was leftover from my first attempt to restructure this. I've removed the extraneous !isExcerpt check here.

these throw if the conversion to std::string fails.  Please take a look at where we already have helpers that sort by odata.id, and make your code similar.

I've found sortJsonArrayByOData() and the functions it calls. I don't see any callers of it, but it looks like what you are referencing.

(I've also found sortJSONResponse() but that looks like it has the same problem I have here.)

I'm wondering if you would be against me making the ODataObjectLess() and odataObjectCmp() functions more generic so that they would accept the key to be used for the sort as on option?

So I would have sortJsonArrayByOData() call with "@odata.id" as key. Then I would add another function which would pass "DataSourceUri" as the key.

> I've found sortJsonArrayByOData() and the functions it calls. I don't see any callers of it, but it looks like what you are referencing.

yep.

> 
> (I've also found sortJSONResponse() but that looks like it has the same problem I have here.)

sortJSONResponse has a lot of problems, the least of which is that it throws.  it doesn't handle human ordering properly.  it could definitely be improved by calling the helper functions that didn't exist at the time.

> 
> I'm wondering if you would be against me making the ODataObjectLess() and odataObjectCmp() functions more generic so that they would accept the key to be used for the sort as on option?

Please do.  I appreciate you asking.  I would only ask that you write some unit tests to make sure the behavior stays consistent.

> 
> So I would have sortJsonArrayByOData() call with "@odata.id" as key. Then I would add another function which would pass "DataSourceUri" as the key.

yep, that sounds like it would work.  It'll be interesting if we looked into whether ordering by URL is technically correct in all cases, but it should be close enough and if we find a degenerate case we'll iterate.
